Situation2: They skim a recent pharmacy newsletter while on break to see what new drugs have been released.
Story: During my lunch break, I usually try to catch up on the latest pharmacy newsletter, scanning for updates on new drug releases and safety alerts. It’s my way of staying sharp, making sure I’m providing the best care to my patients. Today, as I flipped through an article about a promising new anticoagulant, my mentee, Sarah, slid into the seat across from me. She had that eager look, notebook in hand, ready to ask about medication counseling tips. I could see she was hoping for a thoughtful answer, maybe even a story from my own experience. But the newsletter’s headline tugged at me—if I didn’t read it now, I might miss something crucial for my practice. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in: Sarah deserved my attention and guidance, but my patients depended on my up-to-date knowledge. My mind raced, torn between sharing my experience with her and diving into the article that could impact my work. I hesitated, newsletter in one hand, Sarah’s expectant gaze in the other, caught in the tension of wanting to do right by both.
